slides.notes: Welcome the audience and introduce TypeScript. Mention how this talk will cover the core basics to help them get started. Ask: 'How many of you are already using TypeScript or considering adopting it?'

slides.notes: Spend ~2 minutes here. Explain each point briefly: compile-time errors prevent runtime surprises; type safety reduces bugs; productivity improves with better tooling; larger projects benefit from maintainable code. Transition: 'Now let's see how TypeScript achieves this.'

slides.title: TypeScript in Action
slides.content:
TypeScript in Action

// Define a type
interface User {
  name: string;
  age: number;
}

// Use the type
const user: User = {
  name: 'Alice',
  age: 25
};
slides.notes: Spend ~3 minutes walking through the code. Highlight how the `User` interface defines the structure of an object. Point out TypeScript's ability to enforce type constraints, ensuring `name` is always a string and `age` is a number. Ask: 'What happens if we try to assign an invalid value?'

Spend ~3 minutes explaining the differences. Highlight key features with examples. For instance, types support unions, while interfaces allow declaration merging. Transition: 'Understanding these differences helps you decide which to use.'
